body: \text{Determine if the relation } R = \{(x, y) \in A : 3x - y = 0\} \text{ is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive for } A = \{1, 2, 3, \dots, 14\}.
\text{Check if the relation } R = \{(a, b) : b = a + 1\} \text{ in the set } A = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\} \text{ is reflexive, symmetric, or transitive.}
\text{Show that the relation } R = \{(x, y) : x - y \text{ is an integer}\} \text{ is an equivalence relation in } \mathbb{Z}.
\text{In a set of all books in a library, define the relation } R = \{(x, y) : x \text{ and } y \text{ have the same number of pages}\}. \text{Show that } R \text{ is an equivalence relation.}
\text{Verify if the relation } R = \{(a, b) : |a - b| \text{ is even}\} \text{ is an equivalence relation on the set } A = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5\}.
\text{Show that the relation } R = \{(P, Q) : \text{distance of } P \text{ from the origin is the same as the distance of } Q \text{ from the origin}\} \text{ is an equivalence relation.}

\text{Let } R \text{ be a relation in the set of all polygons, defined as } R = \{(P_1, P_2) : P_1 \text{ and } P_2 \text{ have the same number of sides}\}. \text{Prove that } R \text{ is an equivalence relation.}
\text{In the set of natural numbers } \mathbb{N}, \text{ define the relation } R = \{(x, y) : y = x + 5 \text{ and } x < 4\}. \text{Determine if } R \text{ is reflexive, symmetric, or transitive.}
\text{Given the relation } R = \{(x, y) : x^2 = y^2\} \text{ in the set of integers } \mathbb{Z}, \text{ determine if } R \text{ is an equivalence relation.}
\text{Prove that the relation } R = \{(x, y) : x \text{ and } y \text{ live in the same city}\} \text{ is an equivalence relation in a set of people.}
\text{If } R = \{(a, b) : a \text{ and } b \text{ belong to the same department in a company}\}, \text{ show that } R \text{ is an equivalence relation.}
\text{Consider the function } f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} \text{ defined by } f(x) = x^2. \text{ Prove or disprove that } f \text{ is injective and/or surjective.}
\text{For a set } X = \{1, 2, 3, 4\}, \text{ examine if the function } f : X \to X \text{ defined by } f(x) = x \text{ is bijective.}
\text{Verify that the function } f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} \text{ defined by } f(x) = 2x + 3 \text{ is bijective.}
\text{Show that the function } f : \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z} \text{ defined by } f(x) = x + 1 \text{ is a bijection.}
\text{Let } f : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N} \text{ be defined by } f(x) = 3x + 1. \text{ Determine if } f \text{ is one-one and/or onto.}
\text{Show that the function } f : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N} \text{ given by } f(x) = x^3 \text{ is injective.}
\text{Consider the function } f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} \text{ defined by } f(x) = \cos(x). \text{ Is } f \text{ injective, surjective, or bijective?}
\text{If } f : \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z} \text{ is given by } f(x) = x^2, \text{ determine if } f \text{ is one-one and/or onto.}
\text{For the function } f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} \text{ defined by } f(x) = |x|, \text{ is } f \text{ injective, surjective, or bijective?}
\text{Determine if the function } f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} \text{ defined by } f(x) = x + 5 \text{ is bijective.}
